section.para: The element agent specifies a person or organization that played a direct or indirect role in preparing, creating, or editing the data.

At least one <agent> must have an <IRI> that is a tag URN whose namespace matches that of the IRI name. By default, the first such <agent> is taken to be the person or organization ultimately responsible for the current file.

May also be applied to a computer or algorithm that performed a task. This feature is useful for crediting software, e.g., an OCR program used to convert an image, or an algorithm that estimates word-to-word alignments.
Used by: <head>

listitem.para: To attach responsibility for the TAN file to a person or organization, at least one agent must have an IRI element that contains a tag URI whose namespace matches that of the URI name

example.programlisting: <head> ......... <declarations> ......... </declarations> <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="editor"> <IRI>http://viaf.org/viaf/299582703</IRI> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:self</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Joel Kalvesmaki</name> </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> ......... </role> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <declarations> ......... </declarations> <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="editor"> <IRI>http://viaf.org/viaf/299582703</IRI> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:self</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Joel Kalvesmaki</name> </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> ......... </role> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <declarations> ......... </declarations> <agent xml:id="park" roles="editor"> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:self</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Jenny Park</name> </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> ......... </role> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <declarations> ......... </declarations> <agent xml:id="schmidt" roles="Produzent"> <IRI>tag:hans@beispiel.com,2014:selbst</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Hans Schmidt</name> </agent> <role xml:id="Produzent"> ......... </role> ......... </head>

section.para: The element agentrole specifies a time period when one or more <agent>s held one or more <role>s.
Used by: <head>
The element body contains the data

section.para: The element change declares a change made to the current file. Must credit an <agent>, specified by @who, and a time the change was made, specified by @when.
Collectively, <change> elements form the changelog, the revision history of the document.
The editor has discretion as to how long or detailed a <change> should be, or how many should be retained in a changelog. Ideally, <change>s documenting every published version should be retained.
<change> elements may appear in any order, but it is good practice to put the most recent at the top.
Used by: <head>

example.programlisting: <head> ......... <role xml:id="editor"> ......... </role> <change when="2015-07-09-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Started new file.</change> </head>

<TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs" TAN-version="1"> <head> ......... <role xml:id="editor"> ......... </role> <change when="2015-08-21-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Removed empty divs.</change> <change when="2015-07-09-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Started new file.</change> </head> </TAN-T>
<head> ......... <role xml:id="editor"> ......... </role> <change when="2015-03-10" who="park">Created new TAN-TEI file.</change> </head>

section.para: The element checksum specifies some checksum that can be used to confirm the identity of a digital file being referred to. This element contains other elements that define the type and value of the checksum. Must begin with an IRI + name pattern that defines the type of checksum being used (e.g., SHA-1).
This element is useful when it is imperative to ensure that one is using the identical version of a source file.
The checksum will not be generated, checked, or validated by TAN schemas. Validation must be provided by an external tool.
Used by: <inclusion> <lexicon> <morphology> <recommended-tokenization> <see-also> <see-also> <source> <source> <tokenization>

example.programlisting: <source> ......... <name>TEI transcription of boundary marker, set up by C. Julius Zoilos</name> <checksum> <IRI>http://dbpedia.org/resource/Sha-1</IRI> <name>SHA-1</name> <value>8ac1146c86e06071f352bf3cb89614c0a0f0c7ee</value> </checksum> <location when-accessed="2015-05-07">http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/iaph2007/xml/iAph010001.xml</location> </source>

section.para: The element comment discusses issues relevant to nearby data. Must credit an <agent>, specified by @who, and a time the comment was made, specified by @when.

section.para: The element desc provides a human-readable description of a concept, person, or thing referred to by the parent element (or the current document, if the parent element is <head>). <desc> is, in effect, a <comment> about that concept, person, or thing.

Because TAN files may need to be shared across language communities, this data can be stated any number of times in any language (probably in conjunction with @xml:lang), in any Unicode-compliant script. If you provide a comment in multiple languages, it best to make sure that each version says roughly the same thing.

Used by: <agent> <bitext-relation> <category> <checksum> <div-type> <feature> <head> <inclusion> <lexicon> <lexicon> <morphology> <normalization> <recommended-tokenization> <relationship> <reuse-type> <rights-excluding-sources> <rights-source-only> <role> <see-also> <see-also> <see-also> <source> <source> <source> <tokenization> <transliteration> <version> <work>

section.para: The element flags specifies flags to be applied in an XPath expression using regular expressions.
s = dot-all mode; m = multi-line mode; i = case-insensitive mode; x = remove whitespace characters from regular expression; q = no metacharacters
For more see http://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions-30/#flags
Used by: <replace> <tokenize>
The element for-lang specifies a language discussed by the TAN file. This element does NOT name the language of the text enclosed by the parent element, which is the province of @xml:lang.
Values should adhere to BCP (Best Common Practices) 47, http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/bcp/bcp47.txt. For more details see .
Examples: 'eng' (English), 'grc' (classical Greek), 'lat' (Latin)
Used by: <declarations> <lexicon> <morphology> <normalization> <transliteration>

example.programlisting: <declarations ed-when="2015-03-03" ed-who="kalvesmaki"> <for-lang>eng</for-lang> <feature xml:id="quote-cl"> ......... </feature> ......... </declarations>

section.para: The element head contains the metadata (data about the data contained by <body>)

Indicates at a bare minimum the name of the file, the sources, the most significant parts of the editorial history; the linguistic or scholarly conventions that have been adopted in creating the data; the license, i.e., who holds what rights to the data, and what kind of reuse is allowed; the persons, organizations, or entities that helped create the data, and the roles played by each.
section.synopsis:
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, <comment>* & (<name>+, <desc>*, <master-location>*, <rights-excluding-sources>, <inclusion>*,
TAN-A-div.rng: <source>+ ~OR~ TAN-A-tok.rng: <source>, <source> ~OR~ TAN-class-3.rng: <source>* ~OR~ TAN-core.rng: <source> ~OR~ TAN-LM.rng: <source> , <see-also>*, <declarations>, <agent>+, <role>+, <agentrole>*, <change>+)
section.para: Used by: <TAN-A-div> <TAN-A-tok> <TAN-LM> <TAN-R-mor> <TAN-R-tok> <TAN-T>

listitem.para: Any TAN file marked as being no longer in progress must have at least one master-location.
No duplication of @xml:ids is permitted

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Add master-location element after <name> with fixed URL Choosing this option will insert a master-location immediately after name, with the absolute value of the current file's URL.

Schematron Quick Fix: Add master-location element after <name> with relative URL Choosing this option will insert a master-location immediately after name, with the simple filename current file (i.e., no path).

<TEI TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:gomme.1898.ring-o-roses"> <teiHeader type="text"> ......... </teiHeader> <head> <name>Dictionary entry by Alice Bertha Gomme on Ring a Ring o' Roses</name> <master-location>http://textalign.net/release/1/dev/examples/gomme.1989.ring-o-roses.xml</master-location> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="park"> ......... </rights-excluding-sources> ......... </head> <text> ......... </text> </TEI>

<TAN-T TAN-version="1" id="tag:hans@beispiel.com,2014:ringel"> <head> <name>TAN Transkription, Ringelreihen mit Riederfallen</name> <master-location>http://beispiel.com/TAN-T/ringel.xml</master-location> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="schmidt"> ......... </rights-excluding-sources> ......... </head> <body xml:lang="deu" in-progress="false"> ......... </body> </TAN-T>

section.para: The element inclusion specifies a TAN file that is available for inclusion. An inclusion occurs whenever an element X points to this inclusion by means of @include. TAN-compliant validators and processors will fin every X that is found in the included file (checked recursively, against any inclusions adopted by the inclusion) and insert them at that place in the main document.
Only the elements of that name X will be included, not the entire inclusion file. It is up to you to specify exactly which elements should be included.
You may include as many <inclusion>s as you wish, and do not have to use them all.
If you are using an <inclusion> primarily for metadata (<head>) it is recommended to put the value of @xml:id in uppercase. <body> inclusions should be set in lowercase.
For more on this, see
Used by: <head>

listitem.para: No inclusion may introduce a duplicate @xml:id
Inclusion has the same tag id as this document.
Every inclusion must have at least one location that leads to an available document.

section.para: The element IRI contains an International Resource Identifier that serves as a name for the a concept, person, or thing referred to by the parent element. IRIs are explained at .

Any kind of IRIs are allowed: URLs, tag URNs, UUIDs, etc. For names of well-known resources, a URL identifier might be preferred (http://...), to facilitate linked data. If an entity/resource lacks a suitable URL-type name, you may use or coin any other valid IRI, such as a UUID, a tag URN, or an OID. Some concepts may be difficult to find IRIs for. See IRIs.xml for guidance.

Sibling <IRI>s are to be treated as names for the same thing, not as names of different things. Nevertheless, they are not synonymous, only poecilonymic. In the terms of Web Ontology Language (http://www.w3.org/TR/owl-ref/), sibling <IRI>s cannot be assumed to share the relationship owl:sameAs, because they will draw from independent vocabularies that may define similar concepts differently. An element defined with multiple <IRI>s is to be understood as being within the intersection of those definitions.
The element is named IRI instead of URI to encourage internationalization. Alphabets other than the Latin are welcome.

Used by: <agent> <bitext-relation> <category> <checksum> <div-type> <feature> <inclusion> <lexicon> <lexicon> <morphology> <normalization> <recommended-tokenization> <relationship> <reuse-type> <rights-excluding-sources> <rights-source-only> <role> <see-also> <see-also> <see-also> <source> <source> <source> <tokenization> <transliteration> <version> <work>

listitem.para: No duplication allowed: an IRI should appear only once in a file.
If referring to a TAN file, the value must be a tag URN that matches exactly the TAN id

Minio-Paluello, Aristotelis categoriae et liber de interpretatione. Oxford, 1949 </name> </source> <see-also> <relationship which="alternatively divided edition"/> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs</IRI> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello, semantic-based references</name> ......... </see-also> <declarations> <work> <IRI>http://dbpedia.org/resource/Categories_(Aristotle)</IRI> <name>Aristotle, Categories</name> </work> </declarations> </head> </TAN-T>

section.para: The element location declares where an electronic file was found, when.
The URL may be absolute or relative to the current document.
Used by: <inclusion> <lexicon> <morphology> <recommended-tokenization> <see-also> <see-also> <source> <source> <tokenization>

listitem.para: If a file that is referenced is either unavailable or not valid XML, a warning will be returned
If a referenced file is marked as being in progress, a warning will be returned
If a TAN file has been updated since it was last accessed, a warning will be returned
If a sibling <name> or <IRI> is missing, a warning will be returned

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Replace with local uri Choosing this option replace the content with the current filename (without path)
Schematron Quick Fix: Change date to today's date Choosing this option will replace the content of @when-accessed with the current date

Schematron Quick Fix: Replace IRI and name with target values Choosing this option for a TAN file will replace the content of the IRI and name elements with the values found in the first document available.

section.para: The element master-location points to a location where a master copy of the file is to be found. When you use <master-location> you commit yourself to updating the TAN file in those locations. Similarly, if you have completed work on a TAN file and signal that through @in-progress, you must commit yourself to a <master-location>.
The URL may be absolute or relative to the current document.
<master-location> does not disallow the file from being published or distributed elsewhere. It merely points to the main locations where an authoritative version of the file is to be found.
Used by: <head>

listitem.para: Any TAN file marked as being no longer in progress must have at least one master-location.

example.programlisting: <head> <name>Dictionary entry by Alice Bertha Gomme on Ring a Ring o' Roses</name> <master-location>http://textalign.net/release/1/dev/examples/gomme.1989.ring-o-roses.xml</master-location> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="park"> ......... </rights-excluding-sources> ......... </head>

section.para: The element pattern specifies a regular expression pattern to be searched for or matched
Used by: <replace> <tokenize>

listitem.para: Every escape sequence must be recognized by XML schema. See http://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#regexs for details.

example.programlisting: <TAN-R-tok TAN-version="1/dev" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-r-tok:general-1"> <body in-progress="false"> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Pad every cluster of non-word characters with space.</comment> <pattern>(\W)</pattern> <replacement> $1 </replacement> </replace> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Delete end spaces.</comment> <pattern>^\s+|\s+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace> <tokenize> <pattern>\s+</pattern> </tokenize> </body> </TAN-R-tok>
<replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Remove end nonword characters</comment> <pattern>^\W+|\W+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace>

section.para: The element relationship specifies the role that the item named by the parent <see-also> played. This may be either a reserved keyword or an IRI + name pattern that identifies a specific kind of relationship.

para.emphasis: <relationship>'s optional attribute @which takes the following keywords.

listitem.para: IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:auxiliary
Digital or nondigital entity that was helpful in creating or editing the present file. This may be useful for crediting a helpful starting point.

para.emphasis: Keywords that must point exclusively to TAN files:

listitem.para: IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:dependent
Points to a TAN file that uses the current file as a source.

Keywords that must point to TAN editions. Two TAN files are different editions if they are genetically related to each other, but neither one supersedes the other. They share a common editorial history and treats the same basic material but with a different approach. Neither inherently supersedes the other. If they share a common ancestry, they stand in different branches of that ancestry. Editions must not have the same TAN id. They normally differ in the content of <source> or <declarations> or both.
parent edition
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:parent-edition
The edition from which the current one branches.
child edition
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:child-edition
An edition branched off from the current edition.
sibling edition
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:sibling-edition
An edition that shares the same parent as the current edition.
ancestor edition
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:ancestor-edition
An edition that is an anscestor to the current edition.
descendant edition
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:descendant-edition
An edition that descends from the current edition.
cousin edition
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:cousin-edition
An edition that shares the same ancestor as the current edition
Keywords that can be used only by class 1 files, to point to other class 1 files:
alternatively divided edition
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:alternatively-divided-edition
Used by a class 1 file to point to another class 1 file that contains the identical transcription for the same version of the same work on the same textual object, but divides that transcription into a different reference system. If this value is invoked, the concatenated text content of <body> must be identical, after space normalization. This <relationship> is useful for developing a concordance between alternative reference systems for the same text.
alternatively normalized edition
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:alternatively-normalized-edition
Used by a class 1 file to point to another class 1 file that treats the same version of the same work on the same textual object, but normalizes the transcription differently. This <relationship> may be valuable in cases where normalization standards for a particular language are not settled, and users may prefer one convention over the other, but wish to have access to another approach to normalization.

Keywords that must point to TAN versions.One TAN file is a version of another if it derives from it (either directly or through a chain of versions) and if the later version supersedes the older one. Versions of a TAN file stand on a linear path of editorial labor. Differences tend to be minor and reflect a progressive effort to correct errors. Versions have the same TAN id and are distinguished exclusively by the latest ISO-compliant date (see @when and @ed-when).
old version
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:old-version
TAN file superseded by the present file, and part of the same editorial stream. The alterations are considered not to warrant a new @id in the rootmost element.
new version
IRI: tag:textalign.net,2015:relationship:new-version
TAN file that supersedes the present file, and part of the same editorial stream. The alterations have not been significant enough to warrant a new @id in the rootmost element. This is useful for officially deprecating a TAN file without deleting it.

section.para: Used by: <see-also>

listitem.para: Unless you define a relationship through an IRI + name pattern, the value must be:
@which must point to a reserved keyword

example.programlisting: <see-also> <relationship which="alternatively divided edition"/> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs</IRI> ......... </see-also>
<see-also> <relationship which="alternatively divided edition"/> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:object-refs</IRI> ......... </see-also>
<see-also> <relationship which="cousin edition"/> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03:alt</IRI> ......... </see-also>
<see-also> <relationship which="cousin edition"/> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03</IRI> ......... </see-also>

section.para: The element replace contains the equivalent of the XPath replace() function plus parameters, indicating a replacement operation that should be, or has been, applied to a digital file. Used in class 1 and class 3 (TAN-R-tok) files.
Multiple <replace>s will be implemented in document order.
The conventions of this element and its children accord with the definition of the function and its parameters provided at http://www.w3.org/TR/xpath-functions-30/#func-replace
Multiple <replace> values are applied according to the order given.
Used by: <body> <filter>

example.programlisting: <TAN-R-tok TAN-version="1/dev" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-r-tok:general-1"> <body in-progress="false"> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Pad every cluster of non-word characters with space.</comment> <pattern>(\W)</pattern> <replacement> $1 </replacement> </replace> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Delete end spaces.</comment> <pattern>^\s+|\s+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace> <tokenize> ......... </tokenize> ......... </body> </TAN-R-tok>

<body in-progress="false"> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Remove end nonword characters</comment> <pattern>^\W+|\W+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace> <tokenize> ......... </tokenize> ......... </body>

<body in-progress="false"> <replace> <comment when="2015-03-18" who="kalvesmaki">Delete end spaces.</comment> <pattern>^\s+|\s+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace> <tokenize> ......... </tokenize> ......... </body>

section.para: The element replacement contains a string used to replace any occurrence of <pattern>
Used by: <replace>

example.programlisting: <TAN-R-tok TAN-version="1/dev" id="tag:textalign.net,2015:tan-r-tok:general-1"> <head> ......... <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> ......... </rights-excluding-sources> <declarations/> <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="creator"> ......... </agent> ......... </head> <body in-progress="false"> <replace> ......... <pattern>(\W)</pattern> <replacement> $1 </replacement> </replace> <replace> ......... <pattern>^\s+|\s+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace> </body> </TAN-R-tok>
<replace> ......... <pattern>^\W+|\W+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace>
<replace> ......... <pattern>^\s+|\s+$</pattern> <replacement/> </replace>

section.para: The element rights-excluding-sources states the license under which the data is distributed and the rights associated with it, EXCLUSIVE of any rights attached to the source.

If parts of your TAN data fall under two or more licenses, you should (1) split the file (one for each license), (2) find a license that sythesizes the desired licenses, or (3) release the entire file under the most restrictive of the possible licenses.

Diligently check to ensure that the license you have claimed respects the rights of your sources' rightsholders. It is recommended that you license your data under a license that is similar to or slightly more liberal than the one under which your sources have been released.
For more discussion, see
Used by: <head>

example.programlisting: <head> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello</name> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> <IRI>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en_US</IRI> <name>Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License</name> <desc>Exclusive of rights held and licenses offered by rightsholders of the source or sources listed below, this data file, insofar as it constitutes an independent work, is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.</desc> </rights-excluding-sources> <source> ......... </source> ......... </head>

<head> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello</name> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="kalvesmaki"> <IRI>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en_US</IRI> <name>Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License</name> <desc>Exclusive of rights held and licenses offered by rightsholders of the source or sources listed below, this data file, insofar as it constitutes an independent work, is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.</desc> </rights-excluding-sources> <source> ......... </source> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <master-location>http://textalign.net/release/1/dev/examples/gomme.1989.ring-o-roses.xml</master-location> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="park"> <IRI>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/deed.en_US</IRI> <name>This data file is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. The license is granted independent of rights and licenses associated with the source. </name> </rights-excluding-sources> <source> ......... </source> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <master-location>http://beispiel.com/TAN-T/ringel.xml</master-location> <rights-excluding-sources rights-holder="schmidt"> <IRI>http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/</IRI> <name>Creative Commons Namensnennung 4.0 International Lizenz</name> <desc>Dieses Werk ist lizenziert unter einer Creative Commons Namensnennung 4.0 International Lizenz.</desc> </rights-excluding-sources> <source> ......... </source> ......... </head>

section.para: The element rights-source-only states license and rights that are attached to the source of the data.
For more discussion, see
Used by: <source>
The element role specifies a role (responsibility, task, or activity) that one or more <agent>s did in creating or editing the data.
A role may be any activity, e.g., editor, funder, supervisor, data-processor, peer reviewer, patron, defined through the enclosed IRI + name pattern.
For suggestions on IRI vocabularies for this element, see IRIs.xml.
Used by: <head>

example.programlisting: <head> ......... <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="editor"> ......... </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> <IRI>http://schema.org/editor</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Editor</name> </role> <change when="2015-07-09-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Started new file.</change> </head>

<head> ......... <agent xml:id="kalvesmaki" roles="editor"> ......... </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> <IRI>http://schema.org/editor</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Editor</name> </role> <change when="2015-08-21-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Removed empty divs.</change> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <agent xml:id="park" roles="editor"> ......... </agent> <role xml:id="editor"> <IRI>http://schema.org/editor</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Editor</name> </role> <change when="2015-03-10" who="park">Created new TAN-TEI file.</change> </head>

<head> ......... <agent xml:id="schmidt" roles="Produzent"> ......... </agent> <role xml:id="Produzent"> <IRI>http://schema.org/producer</IRI> <name xml:lang="eng">Produzent</name> </role> <change when="2014-08-13" who="schmidt">Anfang</change> ......... </head>

section.para: The element see-also identifies auxiliary entities that were materially helpful in creating or editing the data, or are helpful in understanding the data.
This element is especially useful for may be used to credit 3rd parties who provide a set of raw data that you then edit to bring into better conformity with the <source>.
Used by: <head>

listitem.para: In class 1 files, alternative editions must share the same source.
In class 1 files, alternative editions must share the same work.
In class 1 files, alternative editions must share the same work-version.
In class 1 files, alternatively divided editions must preserve identical transcriptions.

If <relationship> keyword is
dependent
parent edition
child edition
sibling edition
ancestor edition
descendant edition
cousin edition
alternatively divided edition
alternatively normalized edition
old version
new version then parent element must point to TAN file.

If <relationship> keyword is
parent edition
child edition
sibling edition
ancestor edition
descendant edition
cousin edition
alternatively divided edition
alternatively normalized edition then parent element must point to a TAN file of the same type as the current file.
If relationship is dependent, then the current document's id must be found in at least one IRI in the dependent file.

If <relationship> keyword is
parent edition
child edition
sibling edition
ancestor edition
descendant edition
cousin edition
alternatively divided edition
alternatively normalized edition then the current file and the see-also file cannot have the same @id value.

example.programlisting: <head> ......... <source> ......... </source> <see-also> <relationship which="alternatively divided edition"/> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs</IRI> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello, semantic-based references</name> ......... </see-also> <declarations> ......... </declarations> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <source> ......... </source> <see-also> <relationship which="alternatively divided edition"/> <IRI>tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:object-refs</IRI> <name>Categories, Aristotle, Greek text by Minio-Paluello, object-based references</name> ......... </see-also> <declarations> ......... </declarations> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <source xml:id="ger"> ......... </source> <see-also> <relationship which="cousin edition"/> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03:alt</IRI> <name>Edition that renames div types, values</name> ......... </see-also> <declarations> ......... </declarations> ......... </head>

<head> ......... <source xml:id="ger"> ......... </source> <see-also> <relationship which="cousin edition"/> <IRI>tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring03</IRI> <name>Edition that keeps source's nomenclature for div types, values</name> ......... </see-also> <declarations> ......... </declarations> ......... </head>

section.para: The element source identifies the source upon which the data in the <body> of the current file depends.
TAN-T and TAN-LM allow only one <source>. TAN-A-tok allows exactly two. All other TAN formats require one or more.
Used by: <head> <head> <head> <head> <head>

listitem.para: At least one copy of each source must be available to validate file.
After declarations are applied, source must preserve the Leaf Div Uniqueness Rule.
Any TAN file with more than one source must provide an @xml:id to label the source.
Upon validation, if a source is found to have a <see-also> that has a <relationship> of 'new-version', a warning will be returned indicating that an updated version is available

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Replace with new version If the source is found to have a see-also that has a relationship of 'new-version', choosing this option will replace the IRI + name pattern with the one in the source file's see-also.
Schematron Quick Fix: Insert @xml:id Choose this option to add an @xml:id to a source element that requires an id value.

section.para: The element tokenize constructs the equivalent of an XPath tokenize() function plus parameters. Used in class 1 and class 3 (TAN-R-tok) files.
Used by: <body>

example.programlisting: <body in-progress="false"> ......... <replace> ......... </replace> <tokenize> <pattern>\s+</pattern> </tokenize> <example> ......... </example> </body>

<body in-progress="false"> <replace> ......... </replace> <tokenize> <comment when="2015-03-16" who="kalvesmaki">Tokenize on any cluster of nonword characters.</comment> <pattern>\W+</pattern> </tokenize> <example> ......... </example> </body>
<body in-progress="false"> <replace> ......... </replace> <tokenize> <pattern>[\s]+</pattern> </tokenize> <example> ......... </example> </body>

section.para: The element value states the value of a <checksum>
Used by: <checksum>

example.programlisting: <checksum> ......... <name>SHA-1</name> <value>8ac1146c86e06071f352bf3cb89614c0a0f0c7ee</value> </checksum>

section.para: The attribute cert states how certain an agent is of the data governed by the parent element. High = "is probably"; low = "is probably not"; all other values expressed as a real number from 0 (no certainty) to 1 (completely certainty).

This attribute is taken into account after other attributes. That is, @cert is to be interpreted to mean: "Assuming the abovementioned inheritable attributes to be true, I have @cert confidence about the following data:...."
This attribute is inheritable. See
Used by: <align> <ana> <assert> <l> <lm> <m> <report> <tok>

example.programlisting: <body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear"> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 4" val="all"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile e" val="alle"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 3" pos="1"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile e" pos="3"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 3" pos="2"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile e" pos="4"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 3" pos="3"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile e" pos="5"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 1" pos="1, 2"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile a" pos="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 1" pos="3, 4"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile a" pos="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="line 1" pos="5" cert="low"/> <tok src="ger" ref="Zeile a" pos="3" cert="low"/> </align> </body>

<body reuse-type="correlationGeneral" bitext-relation="unclear"> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="4" val="all"/> <tok src="ger" ref="4" val="alle"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="3" pos="1"/> <tok src="ger" ref="4" pos="3"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="3" pos="2"/> <tok src="ger" ref="4" pos="4"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="3" pos="3"/> <tok src="ger" ref="4" pos="5"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="1" pos="1, 2"/> <tok src="ger" ref="1" pos="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="1" pos="3, 4"/> <tok src="ger" ref="1" pos="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="eng" ref="1" pos="5" cert="low"/> <tok src="ger" ref="1" pos="3" cert="low"/> </align> </body>

Along with @ed-who, this forms the Edit Stamp pattern. See

section.para: The attribute in-progress specifies whether the editors of the current file have not yet finished supplying the data, intend to make important changes, or wish to otherwise reserve the right to make major changes.

This attribute does not claim that the data is perfect or that it will not be changed. Rather, it signals to users, especially those who would use the file the object of a <source>, <see-also>, or <inclusion>, the possibility of major, disruptive work.
Used by: <body>

example.programlisting:

Ringel, Ringel, Reihe!
Sind der Kinder dreie,
Sitzen auf dem Holderbuch,
.........

.........

A pocket full of posies;
Hush! Hush! Hush! Hush!
.........

.........
.........
.........
.........

.........
Ring-a-round the rosie,
A pocket full of posies,
Ashes! Ashes!
.........

section.para: The attribute include signals that the parent element is to be replaced by all elements of the same name found in the referred <inclusion>.

Used by: <agent> <agentrole> <align> <ana> <assert> <bitext-relation> <category> <div> <div-type> <equate-div-types> <equate-works> <feature> <implicit-div-type-refs> <lexicon> <morphology> <normalization> <option> <realign> <recommended-div-type-refs> <recommended-tokenization> <relationship> <rename-div-ns> <rename-div-types> <replace> <report> <reuse-type> <rights-excluding-sources> <rights-source-only> <role> <see-also> <source> <split-leaf-div-at> <suppress-div-types> <tokenization> <tokenize> <transliteration> <version> <work>

listitem.para: Must point to @xml:id value of <inclusion>
Must not contain duplicates
All included text needs to be normalized.
Text is not allowed in an element with @include.

Possible validation errors:
Inclusion must be supported in parent element
Replacement element must be found in target inclusion
Inclusion may not be circular
Functions based on inclusions must be applied to elements that have the same name

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Replace content of attribute with all valid values To see a list of all possible valid values, add any invalid content, then choose this quick fix to replace all content with every possible value.

Schematron Quick Fix: Replace with inclusions Any element that has @include must be empty. But if you intentionally open it up and add text, even space characters, this quick fix will be made available upon validation. Choose it to comment out the original element and add after it the complete set of elements found in the inclusion (recursively checked against any inclusions in the included document). This is especially helpful for cases where you wish to use a TAN document as a starting point for a new file.

section.para: The attribute rights-holder specifies one or more <agent>s who hold the rights over the material specified by the parent element (either the data of the current file, or of the source that forms the basis for the data).
A missing @rights-holder implies only only silence, not that the rightsholder is unknown or nonexistent. For more, see
Used by: <rights-excluding-sources> <rights-source-only>

section.para: The attribute TAN-version specifies the version of TAN schemas used (version 1 or 1/dev).
Must indicate at least the major version; may include the minor version.
Used by: <TAN-A-div> <TAN-A-tok> <TAN-LM> <TAN-R-mor> <TAN-R-tok> <TAN-T>

listitem.para: Should be schema major version
Should be schema minor version

tip.para:
Schematron Quick Fix: Update to major version Choose this quick fix to replace the major version with
1

Schematron Quick Fix: Update to major+minor version Choose this quick fix to replace the major and minor version with
1 /
dev

section.para: The attribute when indicates a date or date and time
Used by: <change> <comment>

listitem.para: Future dates are not allowed.
Must be date or dateTime

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Change date to today's date If value is invalid, this quick fix will be made available, to replace the content of with the current date.
Schematron Quick Fix: Change date to today's date-time If value is invalid, this quick fix will be made available, to replace the content of with the current dateTime.

example.programlisting: <head> ......... <role xml:id="editor"> ......... </role> <change when="2015-07-09-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Started new file.</change> </head>

<TAN-T id="tag:kalvesmaki.com,2014:tan-t:ar.cat.grc.1949.minio-paluello:semantic-refs" TAN-version="1"> <head> ......... <role xml:id="editor"> ......... </role> <change when="2015-08-21-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Removed empty divs.</change> <change when="2015-07-09-04:00" who="kalvesmaki">Started new file.</change> </head> </TAN-T>

<source> ......... <name>The traditional games of England, Scotland, and Ireland : with tunes, singing-rhymes, and methods of playing according to the variants extant and recorded in different parts of the Kingdom</name> <comment when="2015-03-10" who="park">This work is to be found at vol. 2, pp. 108-111.</comment> </source>

section.para: The attribute when-accessed specifies when an electronic file was last examined
Used by: <location>

listitem.para: Future dates are not allowed.
Must be date or dateTime
If a TAN file has been updated since it was last accessed, a warning will be returned

tip.para: Schematron Quick Fix: Change date to today's date If value is invalid, this quick fix will be made available, to replace the content of with the current date.
Schematron Quick Fix: Change date to today's date-time If value is invalid, this quick fix will be made available, to replace the content of with the current dateTime.

section.para: The attribute when-from specifies the beginning of a span of time
Used by: <agentrole>
The attribute when-to specifies the end of a span of time
Used by: <agentrole>

listitem.para: Start date must precede end date.

section.para: The attribute xml:id identifies an entity described within an element. Must be unique within a given file. Must consist only of word characters.

No duplication of @xml:ids is permitted

section.para: The attribute xml:lang specifies an ISO (BCP 47) language code that names the language of the text enclosed by the parent element. Values are inherited by all descendants except for those that have an @xml:lang and their descendants.
Values should adhere to BCP (Best Common Practices) 47, http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/bcp/bcp47.txt. For more details see .
Examples: 'eng' (English), 'grc' (classical Greek), 'lat' (Latin)
Used by: <body> <desc> <div> <name>
